items.title: Pat Conroy says China’s claims RAAF aircraft illegally entered its airspace ‘factually incorrect’ – as it happened
items.standfirst: This blog is now closedTurnbull hails Albanese’s handling of Trump meeting but warns ‘warm words don’t build submarines’Australia and the US have signed a critical minerals deal to take on China’s monopoly. Here’s what you need to knowGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe foreign affairs minister was asked about Donald Trump’s remark that he didn’t like the Australian ambassador, Kevin Rudd, and “probably never will” during the White House meeting early this morning.Trump made the testy remark, telling Rudd “I don’t like you either”, at the White House cabinet room table, prompting uncomfortable laughter. Penny Wong told RN the ambassador had done an “extremely good job” getting the meeting between the US president and Albanese:Look, I think those comments were clearly tongue-in-cheek. I’m very pleased that the meeting has been such a success. That is a good thing for our country. It’s extremely good to have this critical minerals deal backed in, and it’s extremely positive for the country to have the president so supportive of Aukus and the delivery of the submarines, which is an important capability for us.Kevin did an extremely good job not only in getting the meeting but doing the work on the critical minerals deal. And the meeting reflects the success of that work. Continue reading...

Penny Wong told RN the ambassador had done an “extremely good job” getting the meeting between the US president and Albanese:Look, I think those comments were clearly tongue-in-cheek. I’m very pleased that the meeting has been such a success. That is a good thing for our country. It’s extremely good to have this critical minerals deal backed in, and it’s extremely positive for the country to have the president so supportive of Aukus and the delivery of the submarines, which is an important capability for us.Kevin did an extremely good job not only in getting the meeting but doing the work on the critical minerals deal. And the meeting reflects the success of that work. Continue reading...

items.title: Australia and the US have signed a critical minerals deal to take on China’s monopoly. Here’s what you need to know
items.standfirst: The move is intended to support the supply of minerals to benefit both countries’ commercial and defence industries – and shareholders are already profitingGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAustralia and the US have signed a critical minerals deal designed to break China’s near complete hold over materials essential to commercial, clean energy and advanced military hardware.Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump have committed to each provide at least US$1bn ($1.54bn) towards an $US8.5bn ($13bn) pipeline of projects in both countries over the next six months to feed their commercial and defence industries. Continue reading...
items.content: The move is intended to support the supply of minerals to benefit both countries’ commercial and defence industries – and shareholders are already profitingGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAustralia and the US have signed a critical minerals deal designed to break China’s near complete hold over materials essential to commercial, clean energy and advanced military hardware.Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump have committed to each provide at least US$1bn ($1.54bn) towards an $US8.5bn ($13bn) pipeline of projects in both countries over the next six months to feed their commercial and defence industries. items.title: October heat records broken across Australia as Sydney braces for temperatures way above the norm
items.standfirst: Birdsville sets new high as BoM forecasts more record hot weather, with heatwave warnings in place in some statesFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastOctober heat records have been broken in several states this week as authorities in New South Wales prepare for temperatures above the norm to hit Sydney and the east coast of Australia.The Queensland outback town of Birdsville broke a new record on Tuesday, hitting 46.1C at 2.28pm local time, according to the Bureau of Meteorology, making it the highest temperature recorded in the state in October. The state’s previous October record was 45.1C at Birdsville police station on 31 October 1995. Continue reading...

The state’s previous October record was 45.1C at Birdsville police station on 31 October 1995. Continue reading...

items.title: Turnbull hails Albanese’s handling of Trump meeting but warns ‘warm words don’t build submarines’
items.standfirst: Former Liberal prime minister scores PM’s White House visit ‘10/10’ and says retention of Kevin Rudd as ambassador to US ‘showed strength’ Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastFormer prime minister Malcolm Turnbull has hailed Anthony Albanese’s meeting with Donald Trump a diplomatic success but says the US president’s emphatic Aukus endorsement doesn’t alter his view that its a “bad deal” for Australia that might never provide the promised US submarines.Turnbull – who sparred with Trump in his firm presidential term – scored Albanese’s White House visit a “10/10” after Trump praised the prime minister as a “great leader”, agreed a multi-billion dollar rare earths deal and publicly backed-in the $368bn pact to equip Australia with a fleet of nuclear-powered submarines. Continue reading...

items.title: Albanese’s critical minerals handout to Trump damages national security — and rewards laziness
items.standfirst: While Donald Trump is a bit late to the party on critical minerals, he's found a loyal dependent in Anthony Albanese to help fix the error. The post Albanese’s critical minerals handout to Trump damages national security — and rewards laziness appeared first on Crikey.
items.content: While Donald Trump is a bit late to the party on critical minerals, he's found a loyal dependent in Anthony Albanese to help fix the error. The post Albanese’s critical minerals handout to Trump damages national security — and rewards laziness appeared first on Crikey.

items.title: Why the Australia-US rare earths deal matters so much for Trump
items.standfirst: P rime Minister Anthony Albanese and US President Donald Trump are crowing about the agreement, but will it make Australia a big player in critical minerals?
items.content: P rime Minister Anthony Albanese and US President Donald Trump have signed an $US8.5 billion ($13 billion) critical minerals and rare earths agreement in a move to break China's stranglehold on the market.The US–Australia Critical Minerals Framework puts rare earths squarely at the forefront of the Australian-US relationship, with Albanese saying there is a "pipeline that we have ready to go".The deal will kick off with both countries paying $US1 billion over the next six months for new projects.READ MORE: 'I don't like you': Trump blasts Rudd during Albo meetingTrump was delighted in securing the agreement with Australia. China earlier this month ramped up restrictions on its rare earth exports. That didn't sit well with the US president, who threatened to call off an upcoming meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping."We work together very much on rare earths, critical minerals and lots of other things, and we've had a very good relationship," Trump said as he sat beside Albanese at the White House."We've been working on that for quite a while."In about a year from now, we'll have so much critical mineral and rare earths, and you won't know what to do with them."READ MORE: World's biggest apps and websites hit by global outageWhat are rare earths?Rare earths include 17 metallic elements in the periodic table made up of scandium, yttrium and the lanthanides.The name "rare earths" is a bit of a misnomer, because the materials are found throughout the Earth's crust. They are more abundant than gold, but they are difficult and costly to extract and process and are also environmentally damaging.The minerals are used to make everyday technologies, from smartphones to wind turbines to LED lights and flat-screen TVs. They're crucial for batteries in electric vehicles, as well as MRI scanners and cancer treatments.Rare earths are also essential for the arms industry and the US armed forces, the world's biggest. They're used in F-35 fighter jets, submarines, lasers, satellites, Tomahawk missiles and more, according to the Centre for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a US think tank.READ MORE: Chilling warning over 3D-printed guns flooding Australia amid crackdownWhy is Australia so crucial?The US sees Australia, a long-standing ally, as an alternative source for rare earths as the critical minerals shape up to become a major hurdle in Washington-Beijing relations.China is the world's largest producer of rare earth elements, with 61 per cent of mined rare earth production, according to the International Energy Agency, and 92 per cent of the global output in the processing stag e. Trump hopes the Australia deal will help break that monopoly.Australia offers three major attractions: it has some of the world's biggest geological reserves : a share market with a record of successfully investing in mining; and a skilled labour force.Are there any hurdles ahead? Economic geographer Lian Sinclair, of the University of Sydney, says vast sums of money are pouring into the Australian rare earths industry: $3.2 billion by Australian government agencies; $2.9 billion from foreign allied governments, including the US, Japan, South Korea and Canada."This is a large amount for an industry with a total global trade of less than US$4 billion ($6 billion) every year," he said. It means without investment in refineries and magnet production in allied countries, Australian miners will continue to either sell into or be outcompeted by Chinese domestic industry.Sinclair says apart from Australian rare-earths mining company Lynas, which sells into the Japanese market, miners are struggling to find potential international buyers.To wean themselves off Chinese rare earths for wind turbines and electric vehicles, the US, Europe and South Korea need to heavily invest in magnet and advanced metal processing industries.Sinclair also points to the environmental cost of Australia becoming a big player in rare earths, with more work needed to be done in planning for managing radioactive waste and building partnerships with First Nations people. - With CNN DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Diplomatic triumph or ‘capitulation’? Albanese found Donald Trump in a heavenly mood but the devil may be in the detail
items.standfirst: Fresh from a tropical holiday, the Australian prime minister caught the US president at his effusive best‘I don’t like you either’: diplomats hold their breath as Trump chides Rudd over previous commentsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAnthony Albanese was so pleased about his first meeting with Donald Trump, so chuffed with the overwhelming – and somewhat unexpected – praise from the president, the prime minister joked that he’d use the endorsements in his campaign ads at the next election.That’s obviously unlikely to happen – consider the effective campaign Albanese ran against Peter Dutton by comparing him to Trump, and the Labor left flank already ropable over what they view as a fawning and “shameful capitulation” over Aukus and critical minerals. Continue reading...

items.title: Jane Norman talks us through the PM's first Trump meeting
items.standfirst: It was Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump's first official one-on-one meeting, where a critical minerals deal was signed and the pair talked AUKUS and trade. National affairs correspondent Jane Norman was at the meeting and said it lasted about 40 minutes, with reporters crammed in and shouting questions.

items.standfirst: President says US has no better friend than Australia but tells ambassador Kevin Rudd “I don’t like you’‘I don’t like you either’: diplomats hold their breath as Trump chides Rudd over previous commentsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastDonald Trump has strongly endorsed the Aukus pact and praised prime minister Anthony Albanese as a “great” leader, but the president’s navy secretary says the US may seek to “clarify some ambiguities” in the nuclear submarine deal.Trump and Albanese also signed a multibillion-dollar agreement for Australia to supply the United States with critical minerals, amid a deepening trade war as China threatens to cut its supply of rare earth elements. But the president also downplayed any prospect of cutting tariffs on Australian goods. Continue reading...

items.title: Desperately seeking submariners: why keeping nuclear-powered boats afloat will be Australia’s biggest Aukus challenge
items.standfirst: A vast and highly trained workforce is needed to command, crew, supply and maintain nuclear submarines. Some say that’s impossible for AustraliaFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast“Vice-Admiral Mead, you’re free to go home … good to see you cracking a smile.”The head of the Australian Submarine Agency had spent a withering three hours before Senate estimates, parrying a barrage of questions about Australia’s ambitious Aukus nuclear submarine plan: interrogatives on consultants, on hundreds of millions of dollars sent to US and UK shipyards, on sclerotic boat-building on both sides of the Atlantic. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Police search property near Toowoomba for man’s body
clusters.neutral_headline: Police Search for Body Near Toowoomba After Murder Charge
bullet_summary: A man has been charged with the murder of Paul Woods, who was reported missing a week ago

items.title: Police search property near Toowoomba for man’s body
items.standfirst: A man has been charged with the murder of Paul Woods, who was reported missing a week ago.
items.content: A man has been charged with the murder of Paul Woods, who was reported missing a week ago.

items.title: Police search rural property near Toowoomba for man's allegedly dismembered body
items.standfirst: A man has been charged with murder as police search for the body of a man who was last seen near Toowoomba more than two weeks ago.
items.content: A man has been charged with murder as police search for the body of a man who was last seen near Toowoomba in Queensland more than two weeks ago.Detectives charged 45-year-old Crows Nest man Shaun Smoothy with the murder of 48-year-old Paul Woods yesterday.Woods' disappearance was first reported to police on Tuesday, October 14.READ MORE: Millions set to swelter as spring scorcher loomsHowever, Detective Inspector Ryan Harmer said he may have come into trouble a week earlier." We've been unable to establish any proof of life from Paul on the fifth," Harmer said."We've spoken to witnesses who have led us to believe that this is obviously a homicide investigation."Police have since established crime scenes at Woods' home in Hampton, as well as Smoothy's property in Cressbrook Creek.The dog squad, police divers and the SES were called in to assist with the search of the large rural property today where police allege Woods was killed and his body dismembered. "At the end of the day, the forensic examination is in its early stages, so we still have a number of days yet to be able to search that property thoroughly," Harmer said. Smoothy is understood to be a house re-stumper and avid hunter.Police say they believe the two men knew each other. "We believe that they know each other, we are still trying to investigate the relationship," Harmer said.Police say Woods was last seen more than two weeks ago, riding an unregistered blue and white Yamaha 450 motorbike on Saturday afternoon, October 5, between the Hampton and Cressbrook Creek area.READ MORE: Which apps and websites were affected by the Amazon Web Services outage?The motorbike remains missing. Anyone with information or CCTV or dashcam of the motorbike in the Hampton, Crows Nest and Cressbrook Creek areas between October 5 and 6 is urged to contact police.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Police are searching a rural property near Toowoomba.

Woods was reported missing, and a body is being sought.

clusters.title: AFL champion Scott Pendlebury launches legal fight over 'missing $2.1m'
clusters.neutral_headline: Scott Pendlebury Sues Former Manager Over Misappropriated Funds

items.title: AFL champion Scott Pendlebury launches legal fight over 'missing $2.1m'
items.standfirst: AFL star Scott Pendlebury has launched legal action against his former manager, claiming he misappropriated more than $2.1 million of his funds.
items.content: AFL star Scott Pendlebury has launched legal action against his former manager, claiming he misappropriated more than $2.1 million of his funds.The Collingwood midfielder lodged the claim for loss and damages against Jason Sourasis in the Victorian Supreme Court on Friday but the statement of claim was released to media this week.Court documents state Sourasis had access to Pendlebury's bank accounts, as he had been providing him financial advice and services since 2013.READ MORE: 'I don't like you': Trump blasts Rudd during Albo meetingIt's alleged between January 2015 and December 2023, Sourasis improperly transferred $2,148,900 from Pendlebury's investment account to accounts associated with Sourasis.There were more than 50 transactions allegedly made in that time frame, ranging from $5000 to $305,000.Pendlebury only became aware the funds were missing in February and he claims the transactions were not made in his interest or in good faith, the documents state.He also alleges Sourasis has not repaid any of the money.Pendlebury also claims he lent $300,000 to Sourasis on March 15, 2023, with the understanding it would be repaid the next day.The agreement changed on March 22 of that year, with Pendlebury accepting it would instead be repaid in six to 12 months with interest, the documents state.READ MORE: Millions set to swelter as spring scorcher loomsPendlebury alleges Sourasis has since refused to pay back the loan or any interest that has been accrued.The footballer claims he has suffered loss and damages as a result of Sourasis' actions.Pendlebury is seeking the return of $2,148,900 with interest, as well as an order for restitution of any traceable proceeds of the allegedly misappropriated funds.He has also made a claim for the $300,000 loan with interest at the rate of 50 per cent a year, calculated from March 22, 2023.Sourasis has been approached for comment, as have Pendlebury's manager and legal representatives.Pendlebury has played 425 games for the Collingwood Football Club, including two premierships in 2010 and 2023.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: AFL star Scott Pendlebury sues former financial adviser

items.content: The Collingwood player alleges Jason Sourasis, who helmed A-League club Western United before its collapse, misappropriated more than $2 million over a decade.

ai_summary: AFL player Scott Pendlebury is suing his former manager, Jason Sourasis, for financial mismanagement.
Pendlebury alleges Sourasis misappropriated over two million dollars of his funds over a decade.
Sourasis previously led A-League club Western United before its collapse.
The legal action concerns the alleged misuse of Pendlebury's finances.
The case involves a significant sum of money and a breach of trust.
